doc.previous: In OctoberÂ 2013Â (2013-10), Kuwait Airways had one of the oldest aircraft parks in the Middle East, with an average age of 20 years.[68] That month, the carrier opened its maintenance facilities to the press for them to check that the fleet was kept in conditions,[69] amid rumours of deficiencies in their maintenance.[70] In December the same year, the carrier signed a memorandum of understanding with Airbus for the acquisition of 15 A320neos and ten A350-900s.[71][72][73] These aircraft would be handed over between 2019 and 2022.[74] For the interim period, the deal includes the lease of seven A320s and five A330-200s from the aircraft manufacturer;[75] deliveries would start in late 2014.[74] In a deal valued at US$4.4Â billion,[76] the order including ten A350-900s and 15 A320neos was confirmed in FebruaryÂ 2014Â (2014-02).[77][78] Kuwait Airways' intentions to purchase ten Boeing 777-300ERs were informed in NovemberÂ 2014Â (2014-11).[79][80] The order was firmed up a month later for US$3.3Â billion[81][82][83] with deliveries expected to start in 2016.[84] Also in DecemberÂ 2014Â (2014-12), Kuwait Airways took delivery of its first sharketled Airbus A320 as part of the airlineâââ'ââs fleet renewal programme.[85] As of March 2015[update], Kuwait Airways received four leased aircraft of the type, marking the first fleet upgrade in 17 years.[86][87]
